Description: Upper body sherd of East Greek, probably Clazomenian, pottery closed vessel, probably a neck-amphora; exterior: painted decoration consisting of five rows of scales with dots in added white at centre of each scale.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Cook states that although the scales are typical of Clazomenian black-figure pottery, they are not exclusive to it and therefore the origin of this specific sherd cannot be confirmed although Clazomenian scales tend to be long (Cook 1952, 143, n. 102, no. 7).
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 120, no. 338, pl. XXXVII)
Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 143, note 102, no. 6)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 239, no. 254)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.131) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4724 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
